ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance in word lengths (excluding spaces) exceeds 8.0, indicating highly inconsistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one word with more than 10 letters; otherwise, it is False.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one word with more than 10 letters; otherwise, it is False.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts as TRUE based on the variance in word lengths exceeding a threshold, which captures the overall distribution and inconsistency of word sizes in the text. The generated rule, however, classifies texts as TRUE if there is at least one very long word (more than 10 letters), focusing on the presence of a single long word rather than the overall variability. These rules do not identify the same key features or patterns; they may often produce different classifications, especially in texts with many short words but high variance, or texts with no very long words but high variance. The core concepts—variance in word length versus presence of a long word—are different, so they are not equivalent in logic or outcome.
